questions.query: What are the display 'options' that can be selected from the EFIS control panel and that are to be shown on the EHSI/ND? 1: Radio beacons, 2: Wx radar, 3: Airports, 4: Data, 5: Waypoints, 6: VDF stations. Choose the most complete answer!

options.text: to store the address of the next instruction.
to add the contents of the program counter (PC) and the instruction register (IR).

the aircraft performance does not match the runway lenght.
the aircraft is not in the correct configuration.

questions.query: Piston engine operating hours are recorded in...

  1. side slips;
  2. aircraft and engine stall;
  3. underspeed and overspeed;
  4. exceeding pitch and roll limits;
  5. wrong take-off and landing configuration.

options.text: Always by a visual and an aural alert when deviating from or acquiring a FMCP altitude.
Always by at least an aural alert when deviating from a FMCP altitude.
Always by an aural alert when deviating from or acquiring a FMCP altitude.
Always by at least a visual alert when deviating from a FMCP altitude.

options.text: Communication via the microphone of the oxygen mask.

options.comment:
Correct.

The cockpit door is assumed to be closed.

questions.query:
In small aeroplanes the composing parts of an instrument are often in one housing.

options.text: The processor and indicator are at the same location.
The whole instrument is in the avionics bay.
The sensor, processor and indicator are at different locations.

options.text: both the barometric altitude and the radio altitude are shown.
the indicated altitude is a combination of barometric altitude and inertial altitude.
there is an analogue and a digital indication of the same altitude.
the altimeter makes use of a straight scale and a circular scale.

questions.query:
The following units may be used to indicate pressure:

  1. Newton (N);

  3. bar (b);

  5. pounds per square inch (psi);
  6. mass per volume;
  7. foot pound.

options.text: When the engine is on at idle power.
When the engine is out (and no wind).

questions.query: The operating principle of the EPR measurement is based on its definition:

options.text: Engine outlet pressure minus engine inlet pressure.
Engine inlet pressure plus engine outlet pressure.
Engine inlet pressure divided by engine outlet pressure.
Engine outlet pressure divided by engine inlet pressure.

questions.query: The operating principle of the EPR transmitter is the measurement of...

options.text: differential pressure between engine total outlet pressure and static pressure.
absolute static pressure in the engine exhaust.
The measurement of absolute pressure in the engine air intake.
the ratio between total pressure in the engine exhaust and in the engine air intake.

questions.query: The correct relation between Kelvin (K) and degrees Celsius (°C) is...

I: The operating principle of a thermocouple is based on the number of free electrons in a wire that depends on temperature and material. II: Thermocouples are interconnected to allow a better average temperature measurement.

options.text: Only I is correct, II is wrong.
I is wrong, only II is correct.

questions.query:

options.text: When measuring with a float that is made from a material that is not temperature dependant.

options.text: measuring the force that is exerted on a springloaded vane.
calculating the decrease in fuel quantity over time.
calculating the difference between original quantity and actual quantity.

options.text: rotating permanent magnet that induces a voltage in a stationary coil.

stationary permanent magnet whose magnetic field is surrounded by a coil.

options.text: oil pressure with help of a planetary gear system.
options.comment: The gears at both ends of te torsion shaft rotate at the same speed, hence the sensed frequency of the pickoff is the same. Depending on the amount of torsion, the two gears are not in phase. Therefore the two AC signals have a phase difference.

the extension of the propeller drive shaft.
the angular speed (RPM) of the propeller drive shaft.

options.text: Measurement of an oil pressure with help of a planetary gear system.

options.text: The amplitude of the vibration determines the indication.

options.text: allow a relative movement between magnet and coil.
calibrate the sensor for the critical vibration frequency.

prevent damage to the magnet in case of very heavy vibration.

questions.query:

options.text: TAT is 20 to 30 degrees higher than the SAT.

questions.query: Which of the following type of angle of attack sensors is named the null-seeking probe and why? alpha vane conical slotted probe

options.text: The alpha vane because it directs itself automatically into the airflow towards a zero angle of attack.
The alpha vane because it uses a servomotor that nulls-out itself with help of a comparator and a servomotor.
The conical slotted probe because the double slotted rows automatically align themselves to the lowest pressure.
The conical slotted probe because the double slotted rows align themselves such that the difference in sensed pressure is zero.

Select the alternative with most correct answers.

options.comment: The altimeter cannot be corrected for the influence of different air temperatures.

questions.query: When the pilot changes the altimeter setting...

options.text: the gain of the mechanism is changed.

options.text: Increase because local speed of sound decreases
Increase because local speed of sound increases

Both TAS and Mach number wil increase.
The TAS will decrease and the Mach number will increase.

options.text: EAS by taking into account the density.

options.text: comprises the necessary sensors, processors and indicators.
may comprise the necessary sensors and processors the indicators are always external.
only comprises the necessary processors the sensors and indicators are always external.

options.text: outside air temperature (OAT), true air speed (TAS), and ice warning.
static air temperature (SAT), precipitation, and vertical speed (V/S).
total air temperature (TAT), angle of attack, and true air speed (TAS).

questions.query: To calculate the TAT, the Air Data Computer (ADC) requires: 1) sensed temperature 2) recovery factor 3) Mach number

options.text: upward, irrespective of aircraft position over earth.

questions.query: The directive force (H) of the earth's magnetic field:

options.text: varies with the heading of the aircraft.

questions.query: The influence of the aircraft magnetic field on the indication of the magnetic compass is called...
Deviation depends on...

options.text: permanent magnetic fields, temporary magnetic fields, and latitude.

questions.query: During a turn at the magnetic equator there wil be:

options.text: A maximum turning error when turning through headings 090° or 270°
A maximum turning error when turning through headings 360° or 180°

questions.query: Which component(s) of the deviation cause(s) the attitude error?

options.text: on the compass swing base or site.

questions.query: Does the flux valve of a gyromagnetic compass suffer from the influence of the aircraft magnetic field?

options.text: Yes, but less than a stand alone Directional Gyro.
No, since the flux valve is an electro-magnetic field sensor instead of a magnetic field sensor.
No, because of the adjustable permanent NS and EW compensating magnets near the flux valve.
Yes, but the gyromagnetic compass is normally fully compensated for.

options.text: to measure the horizontal component of the earth's magnetic field.
to improve the accuracy of the Direct Reading Magnetic Compass (DRMC).
to measure the strength and direction of the aircraft magnetic field.
to counteract (compensate) the influence of the aircraft magnetic field.

questions.query: Any movement of the gyro away from its original position is called wander. Depending on the direction of movement of the spin axis the gyro is said to be drifting or toppling. Topple is defined as:

options.text: Wander in the horizontal and in the vertical plane.

To allow for a higher rotor speed

options.text: the low centre-of-gravity of the rotor housing.
two mercury level switches and two torque motors.

questions.query: What are the output signals of the Vertical Gyro Unit (VGU)?

options.text: two degrees of freedom, and a horizontal spin axis aligned in a N-S direction.
two degrees of freedom, a spin axis aligned with the local vertical, and maintained in this position by an erection system.
one degree of freedom, and a horizontal spin axis aligned in a N-S direction.
one degree of freedom, a spin axis aligned with the local vertical, and maintained in this position by an erection system.

questions.query: The maximum directional gyro (DG) error due to earth rotation is:

options.text: The gyro no longer suffers from apparent drift (wander) when used on the same latitude.
The gyro no longer has to be aligned with the standby compass.
The latitude nut only compensates for drift due to Earth Rate (ER).

a Direct Reading Magnetic Compass (DRMC) controlled by a Directional Gyro (DG)

options.text: it measures Magnetic North instead of True North.
the flux valve precesses at a lower speed than the DG.
it compensates the DG for all forms of drift.

questions.query: In a remote reading magnetic compass (RRMC), the gyro is automatically prevented from drifting by means of:

options.text: a liquid level switch that controls a torquer.
a pendulous suspension system that uses precession.
a cage knob that controls the outer gimbal.

questions.query: Which statement concerning accelerometers is correct?

options.text: They measure accelerations relative to the aircraft which are converted into accelerations relative to earth.
They measure accelerations relative to space which are converted into accelerations relative to the aircraft.
They measure accelerations relative to space which are converted into accelerations relative to earth.

options.text: the travel rate correction is too large near the poles.

options.text: 2 lasers, 2 fully silvered mirrors and a partially silvered mirror
1 laser, 1 fully silvered mirror and 2 partially silvered mirrors

The task of the servo loop of an auto pilot channel is to control:

options.text: The inner loop takes care of the stabilization function and the outer loop takes care of the guidance function.
The outer loop monitors the inner loop.
In case of failure of the inner loop, the outer loop comes into operation.
The inner loop takes care of the vertical guidance function and the outer loop takes care of the horizontal guidance function.

questions.query: During a CAT 3A autoland, the autopilot is disengaged:

options.text: Automatic compensating for drift due to crosswind.

questions.query: The Flight Director (FD) gives...

options.text: pitch- and roll attitude steering commands only.

questions.query: What are the most common symbols of the Flight Director (FD)? 1: Crossbars ('split hairs'), 2: V-bars ('wings' or 'cage'), 3: Flight Path Vector, 4: Course or Track Deviation Indicator, 5: Heading bug, 6: Fast-Slow indicator (speed doughnut), 7: ILS localiser and glideslope pointers.
What is the purpose of the FD indicator?

options.text: To show how much a flight control must be deflected.

questions.query: Automatic pitch trim compensates for:

out of trim forces around the longitudinal axis

questions.query: Manual electric pitch trim operates through:

the ailerons, with Mach Number as the input signal.

the rudder, with the angular rate about the vertical axis as the input signal.

questions.query: Which statement concerning the YD actuator is correct?

options.text: The YD actuator connects to the rudder.
The YD actuator connects to the rudder pedals.
The YD actuator connects to the aileron control wheel.
The YD actuator connects to the ailerons.

options.text: The YD can only operate when the AP is engaged.

options.text: Voice communication is VHF; data communication is UHF.

Voice communication is via sound waves; data communication is via radio waves.
Data communication leads to less misunderstanding and is less time consuming.

options.text: semi-automatically, the pilot has to define the set of data to downlink but cannot define the exact time of transmission.
manually, the pilot has to define the set of data to downlink and the time of transmission.

the altitude alert system only gives a warning when acquiring a FMCP altitude

options.text: EGPWS is the European version of the GPWS.

questions.query: Inputs for the GPWS are:

options.text: Radio Altimeter, Air Data Computer, Flap position, Landing gear position
Landing gear position, ADF receiver, Air Data Computer, Radio Altimeter
Air Data Computer, Flap postion, Flight Control Computer, DME receiver
Landing gear position, Flap position, Radio Altimeter, VOR receiver

questions.query: The TCAS-II surveillance volume is based on...
If two aircraft each generate a coordinated RA (Resolution Advisory), it is necessary that:

options.text: the two aircraft are mode A transponder equipped.
the two aircraft are transponder equipped, and at least one is TCAS II equipped.
at least one aircraft is TCAS II equipped.

questions.query: Traffic Advisories generated by a TCAS (Traffic-alert and Collision Avoidance System) are based on:

options.text: distance to Closest Point of Approach (CPA), irrespective from relative speeds.

questions.query: What is the purpose of the Flight Director (FD) on the ADI?
Which of the following indications can be found on a typical HSI? 1. Heading bug 2. Flight Director 3. Glideslope pointers 4. Fast-Slow indication 5. Track deviation indication 6. Rising runway.
According to CS-25 Color Code Standardisation, the colour of the actual track is <1> and the colour of the active flight plan is <2>.
Which EFIS display may show several modes (presentation formats) and what are these modes?

options.text: The EADI may show the Arc mode and the Rose mode.
The PFD may show the Weather mode and the Terrain mode.
The ND may show the Flight director (FD) mode and the Flight Path Vector (FPV) mode.
The EHSI may show the Expanded Rose VOR mode and the MAP Center mode.

questions.query: Examples of EHSI modes are...
Regarding ECAM/EICAS, what are the system synoptics?

options.text: The procedures to be conducted in case of level 1, 2 or 3 failures.
The presentation of the primary and secondary engine parameters.
The schematical overview of the various aircraft systems together with parameters.

questions.query: EICAM/ECAM shows information from...

ACMS messages can be...

 

Note:

ACMS = Aircraft Condition Monitoring System

options.text: received when there is an ADS Contract.

questions.query:
With the CVR must start recording as soon as...

  1. electric power on;
  2. engines on;
  3. parking brake released;
  4. aircraft in flight.
What are the differences between the Flight Data Recorder and the Cockpit Voice Recorder?

options.text: Construction: FDR normal metal casing, CVR shockproof and fire resistant orange box.
Operation: FDR as soon as engines on, CVR as soon as APU on.
Retention time: 25 hours for the FDR, 2 hours for the CVR.
Location: FDR in avionics bay, CVR in cockpit.

questions.query: When installed, a FDR must at least record...

options.text: attitude, power on each engine, flap position and landing gear position.
use of AFCS, air temperature, primary flight control position and radio altitude.
radio transmission keying, slat position, angle of attack and cockpit warnings.

questions.query: What are the composing parts of the microprocessor?

options.text: Central Processing Unit, Input/Output modules and Memory.
Address bus, Data bus and Control bus.

questions.query: Which databus requires two wires for two-way data communication?
Within computers 'Von Neumann' describes the...

options.text: bus structure: adress bus, data bus and control bus.

questions.query: Why does ARINC-429 makes use of a parity bit?

options.text: to show a warning flag when the data block is corrupt.

questions.query: A stall protection system (SPS)...

options.text: activates the stick-pusher when the stabiliser is about to stall.
prevents the aircraft speed to drop below the minimum manoeuvring-speed.
gives an audio-visual alert when the aircaft is about to stall.
deactivates the turn-coordinator when exceeding the critial angle-of-attack.

questions.query:
A CAT3 automatic landing system, requires the use of automatic...

  1. pilot;
  2. thrust;
  3. pitch trim;
  4. aileron trim.
The Flight Mode Annunciator shows...

options.text: the flight phase of the flight warning system.
the three-dimensional aircraft attitude including airspeed and altitude on EFIS.
the alert and status messages on ECAM/EICAS.
the status of the autoflight system only.

questions.query: The engine synchroniser compares...

options.text: the N1 speed with the N2 speed in a turbine engine.
the thrust (N1 or EPR) between two or more engines on the same aircraft.

questions.query: Regarding alerting systems, a level 3 alert is a...
An Aircraft Heading and Reference System (AHRS) is...

options.text: a solid-state device using MEMS techniques to find aircraft attitude.
a gyroscope in three orthogonal gimbals that measures aircraft attitude.

questions.query: The aircraft clock may derive time from...

options.text: a spiral, wound-up by the flight crew before the flight.

questions.query: The Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) is located on...

options.text: the engine & warning display unit of ECAM/EICAS.
the flight mode control panel as part of the glareshield panel.

questions.query: The stall protection system (SPS) comes in operation when the speed drops below...
When below the alert-height, a failure occurs in a fail-operational autopilot system...

options.text: the AP must be disengaged and the landing must be completed manually.
the other autopilot must be engaged to complete the landing automatically.

questions.query: The take-off warning system (TOWS) gives an alert when the thrust lever is moved forward and...

options.text: the ambient conditions prevent a full-rated take-off.
the selected thrust does not match the required thrust.
the actual engine thrust does not match the selected thrust.

questions.query: A flight data acquisition unit (FDAU) is...

options.text: a fire- and shock resistant flight data recorder.
an electronic unit that converts and buffers information for use in the ACMS.
the computer that sends and receives ACARS text messages.
the computer for uplink- and dowlink messages to/from SATCOM.
